text:
1: Typhlosion, Manectric and Suicune
2: Gold/Silver/Crystal
3: Actually never played any, save for that awful Animorphs game. Though I kinda disagree on Digimon being a Pokemon-clone, though. After watching a lot of the anime (and playing a little bit of the games), I get the feel that they're trying to do different things and in different ways, so I don't feel comfortable "labelling" it as a Pokemon-clone. 
4: X/Y was really, really good, but I still want something that feels...bigger, somehow. Probably just me that's getting old, though. I'd also love to see something a bit darker that'd feel like how G/S/C's Rocket-scenarios and Colosseum felt like when I was a kid. But again, age. : V
5: Gensokyo all the way! On that note, please add some Touhou-music to the list! : D

author: Darknile

text:
Junichi Masuda was a goddamn genius. I've yet to hear a Pokemon soundtrack that lived up to the original excitement and novelty contained within RBY. I was never big into these games, I've played through them a couple times, never owned them. But the soundtrack from the originals still get me. They rock! For as simple as the hardware limitation was, it's incredible he composed such awesome emotional effects.

I agree with pretty much all your thoughts in the end there. I loved Zapdos. And there definitely needs to be more innovation with these games! I can think of a dozen changes that would make me want to play it all over again. Probably the biggest challenge now is that they have so many Pokemon now that if they tried to render them all in 3D and give them realistic motion, it would take an eternity even with a big team. And the game would be massive.

author: Patrick Clement

text: 1. Way too many to have a solid top 3. 2. They all honestly feel like expansions upon the same game (and that's not necessarily a bad thing, more on that in #4). But I have to say the best main game structure is Platinum (all new, non legendary breeds available before postgame), HG/SS B2/W2 had the most robust postgames, and for sheer availability of breeds (especially if you like catching legendaries), OR/AS can't be beat. 3. Often imitated, never duplicated; but if you ask me, especially considering their depictions of the "mons", they all feel like the proverbial oranges to Pokémon's apple. 4. Short answer: If it ain't broke, don't fix it. Long answer: it's definitely better that they don't try to shake the formula up so much it feels like a whole different world or a whole different game. When new games are announced, what I look forward to the most are the new breeds, and the potential for new type combinations. Just give me those, and I'm happy as a clam. 5. Haven't really thought about it too much, but an offhand answer would be the Mario universe. I'd say Kirby, but way too many Eldritch Abominations and Cosmic Horrors to worry about. (Maybe the Panel de Pon universe).

author: HathiFan

text:
Oh man. Pokemon was my childhood, especially back in the R/B/Y and G/S/C days. I remember fondly when Pokemon blew up near the beginning, and everyone watched the show, which was great. I'd say the franchise fatigue is most apparent in the show, and as for the series... the games don't feel as fresh as they used to. Yes, a lot of major changes have now be geared towards the PvP scene. 

But I do give credit to Black/White: Those games have quite an in-game story that's very different from what you'd expect in Pokemon. And yes, I believe they take it to a new level that X/Y didn't reach when it comes to storytelling.

Now for the questions:

1. Charmander, Houndoom, Cyndaquil
2. Gold/Silver/Crystal (I've played those games countlessly... yes I've played them all, even if I didn't need to :P)
3. The Digimon show was cool. Interestingly, my parents said Digimon was incredibly violent, and that I shouldn't watch. I mean, okay. Digimon die, sure. But still. But that's all when it comes to Pokemon clones.
4. Like I said before, I feel like a number of changes to the series have now been addressing the PvP meta-game. When it comes to the game itself, Black/White and X/Y provided some big aesthetic changes, but overall, I feel like there need to be bigger changes to hook me. As it stands, I'm not too crazy about the idea of a potential Pokemon Z with this apparent staleness now
5. I used to want to live in the Pokemon world, with my own Pokemon, going on my own journey :)
author: myohel0

text:
1. Uhh I have way more than 3, so I'll arbitrarily pick Zygarde, Kecleon, and Tropius.
2. Fffff uh Fanmade: PTU, Main: HG/SS, Spinoff: Pokemon XD
3. I prefer the term "'mons game" and... I really like the idea, so I'm not opposed to "copycats" provided they add something interesting to it. A lot of games just throw a new coat of paint on Pokemon without making a battle system as complex or interesting, and I don't think that does a service to either. Beastie Bay is an example of a game taking the 'mons idea and doing something novel with it, and I'm a big fan.
4. Yes and no. I'll probably keep buying it. But after playing Pokemon Tabletop... there are so many places they could go with it, but they keep following the formula because it's easier. I wish they'd make more spinoff games and take it different directions.

author: Malcolm Swoboda

text:
1. Gyarados (it wrecks everything when it gets angry), Charizard (it's a friggin' dragon), and Drifloon (dragging kids that grab on to it to the Pokemon equivalent of Hell is incredibly metal).

2. Gold/Silver/Crystal. If I had spent more time playing Gen 3, I'd go with Ruby/Sapphire/Emerald, but I only played them so I could get all the Pokemon for Gen 4. Diamond/Pearl/Platinum had a lot of cool stuff but the battles dragged s-o-s-l-o-w-l-y, and Red/Blue/Yellow was broken battle-wise (Alakazam and/or Mewtwo = you win). I haven't played Black/White or X/Y, but now that I'm finally planning on getting a smartphone, you better believe that I'm going to spring for Pokemon Go.

3. I haven't played any of them, but as far as I'm concerned, they're all cheap knockoffs of the real thing.

4. Yeah, I'd say so. I'm not a fan of fixing what isn't broken, and Pokemon adds enough in each generation to keep people engaged while not changing what makes the series great.

5. Damn right I'd love to like in the Pokemon world.
author: David E.

text:
1. I'm one of those guys who always change their favourites, because there are so many likeable Pokémon. That's part of the series' charm in my eyes :)

... Though I suppose Treecko, Murkrow and Mareep are a bit closer to my heart than the rest. If I push it.

2. Ruby/Sapphire/Emerald 

3. I actually watched far more Digimon than I did Pokémon, mainly because Digimon aired later. I didn't start thinking of it as a clone until in my middle teens :P

4. I lost interest in the main series after having played through gen 4, partly because I didn't enjoy the 3d graphics, and partly because of franchise fatigue. I do however fully understand that there is a never satiated market and competitive scene demanding their annual update. As long as there are spin-offs that explore the concept in new (more or less) interesting ways I don't complain.

5.Oh yes, without question. Especially if  100 new Pokémon kept pouring in every year!

text:
1. My 3 favorite Pokemon are Bulbasaur, Sceptile, and Pikachu.

2. My favorite Pokemon games are Fire Red and Leaf Green. I've played every gen and really enjoyed Platinum, Emerald, and X and Y, but LG and FR are the ones I always come back to (and have had multiple save files go over 200 hours cuz I'm a crazy person)

3. I really enjoyed the original Dragon Quest Monsters on Gameboy Color! Other than that, I've barely touched any of the clones (though I did enjoy the Digimon TV series)

4. I'm somewhat happy with the way the series has grown, but I don't like how they tend to drop great developments in new games (secret bases disappeared after R/S/E (aside from the remakes), customizing your character only in X and Y, the day/night cycle even has disappeared and then reappeared). I get that they want to keep games unique, but when they drop great developments in the next game, it feels like two steps forward, one step back. 

5. Pokemon would definitely be up there. I'd also love to live in Skyloft, or the Skies of Arcadia world.

author: boyblob

text:
1 : Mewtwo, Greninja, Feraligatr

2 : Gold and his DS remake ^_^

3 : Never playing so i have no thoughts x-D

4 : Not really, the core of the story is basicelly the same at EVERY GAMES. And that's why i quit playing this serie after the 2nd gen, i only return to the saga with Heartgold (Gold DS remake) and play Pokemon X (3ds sold with the game): But that becomes boring to make roughly the same thing in every games.

10 years old child have his/her first Pokemon, some creepy old professor give us a pokedex with the mission to "catch em all", 8 badges to collect + 4 great trainers in the League of the region and the Master at the end, we have a rival who aims to be less and less charismatic at each games since the 2nd gen, a random villain Team, the Pokemon are the ONLY FRAKKING THINGS matter in this world they are no others things above ! (it's like a religion) It's as if in our world the only interest would be for example a competition of tickles and that we would have built a society turning only around that.

I think a complete new story core will be refreshing.

5 : I don't know too many choise @_@
Do the hentaï games with a harem of hot girls count ? X-D

author: Rocket Ken

text: Welcome back, man.
author: VentusxBBSxSpero

text:
1. Wow, i've never thought about this question too much. There's like 100 out of all the 722 Pokemons I really like.

2. Platinum, HeartGold/SoulSilver and Black/White 1

3. Besides watching Digimon on the morning weekends on TV when I was like 6-8 years old, i've never cared too much. 
Pokemon is where it's always been at.

4. (I'll get to that question, but first some some story for perspective's sake) I got my first Pokemon game (Red) in 2000 when I was 5, loved it, got the sequels Gold/Silver/Crystal and Ruby/Sapphire/Emerald the years later, plus the gen 1 remakes. Loved them aswell, 3rd generation was probably the highlight given that it was the time when all my buds at school were in to Pokemon. years later, in 2007 most of them did not care anymore at all. It was just some small kids thing to them, and for a while, I agreed, mainly because the new games Diamond/Pearl had just come out. I did not have anywhere near as fun playing those games as I did with previous games in the series, so then I just thought (at 12 years of age no less!) that I had become too old for it to still be very fun. Almost 3 years later, having played next to nothing Pokemon during that time, I saw that remakes of Gold and Silver were out. After lots of consideration, I decided to try again given how much i loved my Pokemon Gold back in the day. Probably the best gaming decision I've ever made. But then I thought, what make me dislike Diamond/Pearl so much (in comparison that is)? Well, after reading about it i've seen that I was not the only one, and that most Pokemon fans think that the "complete game" every generation has in Platinum is far better and fixes most of the flaws of D/P, after reading that, I decided to get Platinum and WOW they were so right, so it was never about me growing too old, it was that the first games in gen 4 was really lackluster. Ok are you still reading? Good, this is where i'll start answering the question; HeartGold/SoulSilver and Platinum are easily the best games among what I like to call the 'conservative Pokemon games' after them, we got Black/White, and they were the first games that truly felt like sequels to the established formula. And it was amazing, it truly was the evolvement of the franchise that was needed. Then we got direct sequels to them, and they were still good, but did not improve at all on what made the first so great. Instead they added lots of random stuff which had nothing to do with what people like about Pokemon, and they did not make the story anywhere near as interesting as in B/W 1 which was a shame. And then a year later we got...X/Y I was really afraid that it would ignore everything that made B/W 1 so great and just go back even further than what B/W 2 did, and my fears unfortuneatly turned out to be correct. Extremely sad, what we got was another game in the 'conservative Pokemon series' with ridiculously lackluster content on top of that.

tl;dr: If you've only played X/Y these last 10 years, Supra, then go back like you say you will and at least play B/W 1. They're FAR bigger improvements from the games released 10+ years ago, than what X/Y is.

5. Oh and I don't think i'd like to live in a Pokemon world considering there are so many things about that world which doesn't correlate to real world logic, if I were to elaborate on that, this part would probably be longer than #4....
author: NetConsole

text: +NetConsole Interesting, I'm definitely intrigued to try Black/White then!

author: Alessandro Cristiano

text:
1. Zoroark, Bisharp, and Victini (too cute) 
2. Black/White, got me back into the series after only playing FireRed and a bit of Sapphire as a kid before losing interest in the series. I remember seeing the animated sprites on a commercial and going, whoa! They finally upgraded the graphics, and I still love those sprites over the 3D models.
3. Eh, no thoughts really. I always wanted to watch Digimon though.
4. No, Mega Evolutions were a good idea in concept, but just dumping them on the most popular pokemon causes an even larger power creep. They really should've given more typically weaker 'mons it so they could keep up with the best (cough Flygon cough). I can only see Megas causing stagnation as more and more flood the series :/
5. The world of Xenoblade (if I'd be safe/have strong traveling partners) comes to mind, Pokemon'd be nice too having a Zoroark disguise as me and cause all kinds of shenanigans would be so fun.
author: 21stCenturyBoy

text:
1. Mudkip, Blissey, and Gardevoir

2. HeartGold/SoulSilver

3. I liked the Digimon animes as a kid but that's really it. Never played any of the games besides Rumble Arena 2.

4. No. I played Pokemon often until a couple years ago, and the games are too similar that I've stopped playing all together. They're still extremely easy. The AI is completely braindead, and the trainers' Pokemon are horrible. The competitive play is extremely RNG based. Rather than throw in new gimmicks, they need to change the style of battles, while still keeping the core mechanics. Also, I find a lot of the end content, like Battle Mansion, extremely grind heavy and tedious.

5. If I stopped living in the world when the game was completed, I'd choose Dark Souls. I just want to actually experience that world with my own two eyes once in my life. However, if I have to live there forever, it'd be Pokemon.
author: lacoot

text:
1. Vaporeon was my first level 100 pokemon and i still have aqua to this day, Arcanine was my first love and was my favorite pokemon for such a long time, Gardevoir is probably my third favorite, there were a lot of pokemon i considered for this spot but gardevoir just hits a lot more nostalgia points for me
2. my favorite pokemon main series game is pokemon white 2. the story was downgrade from white 1, but the amount of content they put in the game was ridiculous. i spent hours on the game and was still playing when x and y came out. my favorite spinoff would have to be pokemon colosseum. i love the different tone they took with the game and how they made the entire game double battles. i also liked the limited set of pokemon because it forced you to choose pokemon you probably would have never chosen.
3. I don't mind pokemon clones, but i'll probably never really play them, the closest i got was wanting to play digimon. You just cant beat pokemon.
4. I'm not really sure about my answer to this question. I feel like each iteration takes several steps forward, but also a few backwards. for example, pokemon black and white had phenomenal story, but the pokemon designs were probably my least favorite (i actually like the vanilluxe line) and i didn't really play the game that much after i beat the main storyline. there just wasnt that much to do. then with white 2, they added all sorts of crazy new content that expanded the game in incredible ways! but the story was meh and it was still the same set of pokemon. then with x and y, they added all sorts of stuff like trainer customization and megas fairy and 3d and skating and different battles and the possibility of two type moves and made it way easier to get into competitive battling, and while they didnt have a lot of pokemon, it was probably the best batch that we've gotten since hoenn, in my opinion. but the game had incredibly little afterstory and i havent played it since. then ORAS didn't really do anything to fantastically new other than travelling on latios, but it was just a remake and they left out the best parts of emerald while heartgold kept the extra stuff from crystal. we still have yet to see our pokemon outside of their pokeballs since heartgold. i really think that they could create a fantastic game if they kept every good feature they've introduced, but they just keep taking it all away.
5. The world I want to live in the most is the avatar world with all the bending, but pokemon is an incredibly close second.
author: Mebrother9

text:
Amazing choices for OST, but my favorite part of this video - and why it's one of my favorite videos from you - is your commentary in the video.  It was amazing reading so much enthusiasm for a game that you loved as a child and growing up, and it made me remember my experience with Pokemon growing up, too.  I'm not sure if this is going to be a regular new thing, but I hope you consider doing it for some particularly memorable future uploads, too!

As for your questions...  
1.) Bulbasaur was my first starter, so he always holds a special place.  Otherwise, Metagross and Serperior are high up there.
2.) Ungh.  Either Heart Gold or Black 2.  Can't choose...  HG for its atmosphere and the culture I can feel in the world.  It also has my favorite collection of Pokemon (Gen 1+2).  And Black 2 for its content.  So many places to explore, so many things to do.  Also, I like the story.  Recently, I've grown rather fond of Omega Ruby, but some factors hold it back for me.  Amazing atmosphere, though.  The world feels more alive and rich than almost any other Pokemon game.
3.) I ... am of the party that doesn't call Digimon a Pokemon clone.  But if we're talking monster game genre in general, Monster Rancher and Digimon were my favorites.  I think these two have different enough focuses from Pokemon that make them unique and fun to play.  Ni no Kuni (if you can count it a monster game, hah) is a good one, too, and we'll all see how Youkai Watch is shortly in the future.
4.) I think there are many changes that can be done to make the game more dynamic, but I respect the slow pace they're making the game.  Their target audience and their high stakes in the game prevent them from shaking up the main series too much.  That's why there are the spin offs that can be more creative and more daring.  I also have split opinions on the way the emphasis is more on story now; sometimes it works (ORAS) and sometimes it doesn't (XY) for me.  I remember in RBY it was a simpler time.
5.) Pokemon, yes.  Digimon, too.  These are two of my favorite childhood series, and I remember pretending that I had Pokemon physically with me when I was outside.  Imaginary monster friends, haha.

By the way, if you're interested in trying spin-offs, I'd like to suggest PokePark 2 for the Wii.  It's an often looked-over spin-off, but I'd always thought the Tales series battle scheme would work well with Pokemon (four special moves, it's practically asking to be adapted), and PokePark 2 pulled it off.  I didn't see it on the list, so I wasn't sure if you'd played it, but I can definitely recommend it :)

author: Piano Elf

text:
Man, reading about your Pokémon experience made me feel nostalgic for mine. It was very similar to yours - a fascination with Red/Blue/Yellow which turned into an addiction with Gold/Silver as well as religiously watching the anime and collecting Pokémon card. I wish I could bottle up the wonder I felt when I found out you could return to Kanto in Gold/Silver. Unlike yourself SD, I didn't experience franchise fatigue until Diamond and Pearl. I loved Ruby and Sapphire and poured just as many hours into those as I did with the first two generations. Diamond and Pearl came along... and I was just worn out on the series. I know they're solid games, but I was fatigued with the series. Like you, I returned with Pokémon X and had an utter blast, and I enjoyed reliving Sapphire and Ruby with their 3DS remakes. As for your questions:

1 - My three favourites are Umbreon, Oddish and Bellossom. I fell in love with Umbreon's design right away. I had a stuffed toy of Oddish which I got from a fast food restaurant so she became one of my favourites too. As for Bellossom, I always hated evolving Oddish into Vileplume as I didn't like its design, but I really liked Bellossom's.

2 - Gold/Silver, no doubt.

3 - I've never played any, so I can't chime in! Digimon World is the closest game I've played to Pokémon, but I think it's more of a traditional RPG than a monster catching RPG.

4 - Not really. X was great, but there seems to be a push towards either competitive play with IVs/EVs which doesn't interest me whatsoever and towards a more casual audience with the F2P 3DS spin-offs and with Pokémon Go. I just want a healthy middle ground, which I'm sure I'll still get in the main-line Pokémon games - I likely won't get as fascinated with Pokémon as I did in my younger days though due to the end-game being more competitive focused.

5 - Pokémon would be up there, but I'll always thought living in Mass Effect's universe would be amazing.

Apologies for the wall of text! Looking forward to hearing your upcoming VGM picks - it helps me build my VGM playlist and remember some old faves.
author: JayMoyles

text:

I'm basically done with pokemon by this point, except for the nostalgia, so I really have no opinion on the matter.

author: Yuki Mizuno

text:
1. Tough choice, but probably Treeko,(my first starter Pokemon and who I was in the first Pokemon Mystery Dungeon) Skitty, (cutest little thing in existence) and Gardevoir(more Mystery Dungeon Memories)

2. Tie between Pokemon Sapphire, Pokemon Black, Pokemon Black 2, and Mystery Dungeon:Red Rescue Team

3. Never played one, but Telefang looks interesting

4. Honestly, I didn't care much for Generation 6. I really don't know why I don't like it; maybe it's the full 3D aspect; maybe it's the increasing complexity, I don't know. Now, Pokemon Go, IMO, is a step in the right direction. Don't get me wrong; I want Pokemon to stay on Nintendo consoles. It just seems right, in a way that it really is the closest thing to Mr. Tajiri's original vision of Pokemon, and definitely is something I only could have dreamed of as a child.

5. Pokemon all the way! It may not be the most perfect world, but it's the world for me. 

Thank you SupraDarky, for bringing back memories and creating new ones. :3
author: Aegis29

text: My three favorite Pokemon are Charizard, Gengar and Zapdos, but I don't have much else to say on the series considering I haven't played many of the other games.  I'm not one for grinding, and collecting in games has never been too much of an interest to me, so my Pokemon experience has always been to get my 6 favorite Pokemon and use them.  Admittedly, that even gets tedious after 2 playthroughs, which Is why I don't play Pokemon that much.  Still, the series is a surprisingly deep and fun RPG, and the franchise undoubtedly played a large part in my childhood.
